abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Services
            Development Project for Azerbaijan were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the project underestimated the Technical
            Assistance (TA) needs in AzerPost and did not initially
            suggest an efficient solution in the project design. During
            the implementation, the project developed a holistic,
            multi-pillar approach to improve access to finance and
            payment services. It established a legal and governance
            framework for AzerPost to increase access to finance. Until
            early 2006, AzerPost lacked a dedicated director responsible
            for the project implementation, contributing to slow project
            launch. Due to his background, the new Deputy Director
            responsible for the project played a key role in advancing
            project implementation, raising and getting issues resolved
            with the key stakeholders throughout the project life. The
            World Bank lacked sufficient Information Technology (IT)
            procurement resources in the country office (there were two
            IT procurement experts for the entire Europe and Central
            Asia Region). This increased overall supervision costs and
            slowed down procurement process for key IT procurement
            packages significantly, respectively. Therefore, it is
            important to provide the staff and financial resources
            according to the complexity of the projects so that the lack
            thereof would not cause delays.

repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Financial Services Development
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Financial Services
            Development Project for Azerbaijan is to increase efficient
            access to financial services in targeted cities, rayon
            centers and rural areas and support adoption of a strategic
            framework for an efficient payment system infrastructure.
            The major changes include: (i) reformulated project
            development objectives (PDO), outcome and component
            indicators and targets to more closely measure the outcomes
            of the original and restructured project expected by the
            closing date; and (ii) reduction of the scope of the
            component two and alignment of its description with changes
            during implementation. The minor changes include: (a)
            reallocation of credit proceeds between disbursements
            categories to meet the project needs; (b) revised project
            financing and costs to reflect changes during
            implementation; and (c) a revised disbursement schedule to
            reflect the initial implementation delays and the recently
            extended implementation period. Expected outcomes include:
            (1) increased efficient access to financial services in
            targeted cities, rayon centers and rural areas; and (2)
            adoption of a strategic framework for an efficient payment
            system infrastructure.

6047373.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rural development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Azerbaijan Financial Services
            Development Project aims to facilitate the implementation of
            the country's Poverty Reduction Strategy and economic
            reform programs related to regional development and
            development of  the non-oil sector through improvements of
            the access of  the rural population to financial services
            and improvements in the financial architecture. There are
            three project components. (1) A component for Azeri Post to
            build the financial service capacity in rural areas that are
            presently undeserved or not served by the banking system and
            to improve access to basic business infrastructure and for
            delivery of  Government services; (2) a component for the
            National Bank, to finalize the development of  the National
            Payment System Architecture, including introduction of
            electronic payment services and management of  payment
            risks, interface with the large billing systems and
            integration of  rural areas; and (3) a project management
            component. The proposed project would finance investments,
            technical assistance and training.
